qas.question: What can a bishop absolutely prohibit?
Where did synods prohibit all hunting at?

answers.text: Milan, Avignon, Liège, Cologne, and elsewhere

qas.question: What did Benedict XIV declare about decrees prohibiting hunting?
Who can prohibit hunting to the clerics?
Declaration that decrees are not severe was done by who?
What did Synods at Milan, Avignon, Liege, Cologne, and elsewhere do?

answers.text: prohibit all hunting to the clerics

qas.question: What happens if a bishop takes part in hunting?
In what areas was it allowed for bishops to hunt?
What did Benedict XIV say allowing hunting conformed to?
Who was the only pope who took part in quiet hunting?
What law was put in place to protect the right of hunting by Benedict XIV?

context: Nevertheless, although a distinction <a0_0>between lawful and unlawful hunting<a0_0/> is <b7_0>undoubtedly permissible<b7_0/>, it is certain that a <a4_0>bishop<a4_0/> can absolutely <a6_0>prohibit <a1_0>all hunting<a1_0/> to the clerics<a6_0/> of his diocese, as was done by synods at <a2_0><b8_0>Milan, Avignon, Liège, Cologne<b8_0/>, and elsewhere<a2_0/>. <a5_0><b10_0>Benedict XIV<b10_0/><a5_0/> (De synodo diœces., l. II, c. x) declared that such synodal decrees are <a3_0>not too severe<a3_0/>, as an absolute prohibition of hunting is more conformable to the <b9_0><b11_0>ecclesiastical law<b11_0/><b9_0/>. In practice, therefore, the synodal statutes of various localities must be consulted to discover whether they allow quiet hunting or prohibit it altogether.
